entry.title: Understanding and Integrating SAP Signavio Process Insights with On-Premise S/4HANA
entry.content:
Business Process Visibility Challenges

Most organizations struggle to clearly answer questions about how their business processes run. Questions such as how long it takes to process a customer order or why invoices are delayed often lead to manual investigations. Teams review emails, interview stakeholders, and build spreadsheets, only to discover fragmented and inconsistent process execution.

This lack of visibility makes it difficult to identify bottlenecks, understand delays, and prioritize improvements. Without reliable data, decisions are often based on assumptions rather than facts. SAP Signavio Process Insights is designed to address this challenge by providing data-driven visibility into how processes execute across enterprise systems.      

SAP Signavio Process Insights (https://www.signavio.com/products/process-insights/) is a cloud-based solution that provides data-driven insights into business processes, identifying inefficiencies and offering recommendations for improvement​. SAP Build Process Automation enables users to automate business processes with low-code/no-code tools, integrating workflows, RPA, and AI for enhanced efficiency. It simplifies automation design and deployment.

Supported Source Systems Overview

SAP Signavio Process Insights can connect to one or multiple source systems to analyze business processes. Supported systems include CRM, ECC, Ariba, S/4HANA, EWM, SRM, and TM.

There are two ways to connect SAP Signavio Process Insights with your on-premise system.

Direct

  • When source system meets all the prerequisites
  • Can be upgraded anytime in case new features come with new or updated prerequisites
  • You do not plan on connecting multiple source systems

Through intermediate system

  • When source system does not meet the requirements
  • Cannot be planned for maintenance activity as needed
  • You do intend to connect multiple source systems

The focus of this blog is on connecting an on-premise S/4HANA system directly to SAP Signavio Process Insights.

Prerequisites To Start The Integration

Before starting the integration from the backend system to SAP Signavio Process Insights, a dedicated SAP BTP subaccount must be created. The detailed steps for preparing the subaccount are documented in SAP Help Portal.

In addition, the supported versions of the ST-PI and ST-A/PI plug-ins must be installed in the on-premise S/4HANA system. The required versions and SAP Notes depend on the system release and can be found here.

Why Update ST-PI plug-in?

SAP Signavio Process Insights uses the ST-PI plug-in to connect your SAP on-premise source system to your cloud tenant.

The ST-PI plug-in requires an encrypted HTTPS outbound connection to SAP BTP to be set up. Using the plug-in and the HTTPS connection allows you to trigger the data transfer yourself from your SAP on-premise system. This means that the Cloud Connector is not needed and cannot be used to connect your system to your SAP Signavio Process Insights application running on SAP BTP.

The ST-PI plug-in includes functionality from SAP Cloud ALM. Other functionalities of the SAP Cloud ALM solution are not used, only the ST-PI plug-in in your system is leveraged. Data from your SAP on-premise system is sent directly to SAP Signavio Process Insights, it's not stored in SAP Cloud ALM. You do not need to use the SAP Cloud.

Required Users and Roles

If you have installed an ST-PI version that is no longer supported and are using a direct system connection, you would need to assign the following roles for the Background user:

  • SAP_MANAGED_BPOANA_ALL
  • SAP_SDF_ALM_METRIC_PUSH_FND
  • Business ALL profile which includes the Authorization object M_MTDI_ORG.

NOTE: If the PFCG role SAP_SDF_ALM_METRIC_PUSH_FND does not exist, implement SAP NOTE 3372078 in the system.

Once all the pre-requisites are met, the connection setup can begin. The steps are as follows:

Step 1 - Depending on the installed ST-PI version, the setup is performed using one of the following transactions:

Tcode: /n/SDF/PIN_SETUP or /n/SDF/ALM_SETUP

Step 2 - Provide Target ALM Destination. You can choose an existing connection or create a new one.

Step 3 - Copy the service key from the Signavio service instance, under Credentials column in SAP BTP.

Step 4 - Copy the URL (Line 23) from the service key credentials to paste in the Root URL field (Step 5).

Step 5 - Click on “Create/Update Destination” button in your source system. In the popup, click on “Paste Service Keys” button and paste the service key retrieved in Step 3.

Step 6 - Enter the background username and click on “Register” button. Once registered successfully, LMS_ID will be generated.

Step 7 - Click on “Activate use-cases” button, select Business Process Monitoring and save.

These steps establish the connection and enable data transfer from S/4HANA to SAP Signavio Process Insights.

Initial Validation and Basic Troubleshooting

If HTTP connection issues occur, the RFC destination created during setup should be checked in SM59. A common issue is missing proxy server or port information.

Both the SM59 destination and the ALM setup configuration should be reviewed to ensure that data can flow from S/4HANA to SAP Signavio Process Insights.

Once the connection is established, data availability can be verified in the Signavio tenant by checking the Administration section.

This blog explains how SAP Signavio Process Insights integrates with an on-premise S/4HANA system using a direct connection approach. It is intended to provide clarity on prerequisites, architecture, and the overall setup flow.

For detailed configuration steps and troubleshooting, the official SAP documentation should be used as the primary reference.

Please refer to:

https://help.sap.com/docs/BPI/f5642e5272c1465986661c763b56213d/bfda0682adc0477984933ea975a4c2d1.html#required-preconfiguration

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1PBdtAgTsl8&t=230s

entry.title: Filtering the Filtered Data with Two Different Events in SAPUI5
entry.content:
(Icon Tab Bar + Live Search Filtering)

1. Introduction

In SAPUI5 applications, users often need to filter data quickly based on different parameters—such as status, category, or keyword. While using only one filter works in simple cases, real applications require combining filters to offer a better user experience.

In this blog, I will explain how to implement dual filtering using:

  • Icon Tab Bar – to filter by status

  • Live Search Field – to filter inside already filtered data

  • Combining both filters so only the relevant records are shown

With this approach, users can first select a category (like COMPLETE or PENDING) and then type a search term to refine the results further.
2. Main Content (Implementation Details)

2.1 Output Screens

After filtering all Completed status using Icon Tab Bar

Now applying fuzzy search on already filtered data (Completed + search 'S')
Final refined results after applying both filters:

2.2 XML View Code

<mvc:View controllerName="serch.controller.View1"
     xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc" displayBlock="true"
    xmlns="sap.m"
    xmlns:l="sap.ui.layout"
    xmlns:f="sap.ui.layout.form"
    xmlns:core="sap.ui.core">
    <Page id="page" title="Filtering Filterd Data" titleAlignment="Center">
        <IconTabBar id="idIconTabBar" select="onFilterSelect" class="sapUiResponsiveContentPadding">
            <items>
   <IconTabFilter text="ALL"
                icon="sap-icon://wallet"
                key="ALL"
                >
                </IconTabFilter>
                <IconTabFilter
                text="COMPLETE"
                icon="sap-icon://begin"
                key="COMPLETE"
                iconColor="Positive"
                >
                </IconTabFilter>
                <IconTabFilter
                text="INCOMPLETE"
                 icon="sap-icon://error"
                 key="INCOMPLETE"
                  iconColor="Negative"
               >
                </IconTabFilter>
                <IconTabFilter
                text="PENDING"
                 icon="sap-icon://pending"
                 key="PENDING"
                  iconColor="Critical"
                   >                        
                </IconTabFilter>
            </items>
                    <content>
                        <Table id="table1" items="{oModel>/results}" mode="SingleSelectMaster">
                            <headerToolbar>
                                <Toolbar>
                                <SearchField id = "fez" liveChange="LiveChange"  width="20%"></SearchField>
                                    <ToolbarSpacer />
                                </Toolbar>
                            </headerToolbar>
                            <columns>
                                <Column>
                                    <Text text="Empid" />
                                </Column>
                                <Column>
                                    <Text text="Name" />
                                </Column>
                                <Column>
                                    <Text text="Salary" />
                                </Column>
                                <Column>
                                    <Text text="Status" />
                                </Column>
                            </columns>
                            <items>
                                <ColumnListItem type="Navigation" press="onNavigation">
                                    <Text text="{oModel>Empid}" />
                                    <Text text="{oModel>Name}" />
                                    <Text text="{oModel>Salary}" />
                                    <Text text="{oModel>Status}" />
                                </ColumnListItem>
                            </items>
                        </Table>
                    </content>
    </IconTabBar>
    </Page>
</mvc:View>

Code  For  Controller:

sap.ui.define([
  "sap/ui/core/mvc/Controller",
  "sap/m/MessageToast",
  "sap/ui/model/json/JSONModel",
  "sap/ui/model/Filter",
  "sap/ui/model/FilterOperator"
],
function (Controller, MessageToast, JSONModel, Filter, FilterOperator) {
  "use strict";
  return Controller.extend("serch.controller.View1", {

    // Initialization function, called when the controller is initialized
    onInit: function () {
      this.read(); // Call read function to load data initially
    },
    // Function to read data from the backend service (OData)
    read: function () {
      var that = this;
      var oModel = this.getOwnerComponent().getModel();  // Get the OData model from the component
      oModel.read("/Zentity_empSet", {
        success: function (odata) {
          var oModel1 = new JSONModel(odata);  // Create a new JSON model with the received data
          that.getView().setModel(oModel1, "oModel");  // Set the JSON model to the view
        }
      });
    },

    // Function to apply filters based on the selected status from a dropdown
    onFilterSelect: function (oEvent) {
      this.selectedStatus = oEvent.getParameter("key");  // Get the selected filter key
      this.sKey = this.selectedStatus;  // Store the selected key for later use
      var oTable = this.getView().byId("table1");  // Get reference to the table control
      var oBinding = oTable.getBinding("items");  // Get the binding for table items
      var aFilters = [];  // Initialize an empty array for filters

      // Apply filters based on the selected status
      if (this.sKey === "COMPLETE") {
        var statusFilter = new Filter("Status", "EQ", "COMPLETE");  // Filter for "COMPLETE"
        aFilters.push(statusFilter);  // Add to the filters array
      } else if (this.sKey === "INCOMPLETE") {
        var statusFilter = new Filter("Status", "EQ", "INCOMPLETE");  // Filter for "INCOMPLETE"
        aFilters.push(statusFilter);
      } else if (this.sKey === "PENDING") {
        var statusFilter = new Filter("Status", "EQ", "PENDING");  // Filter for "PENDING"
        aFilters.push(statusFilter);
      } else if (this.sKey === "ALL") {
        this.read();  // If "ALL" is selected, reload data without any filters
      }

      oBinding.filter(aFilters);  // Apply the filters to the table
    },

    // Function to filter table data dynamically based on user input in the search field
    LiveChange: function(a) {
      var srchVal = a.getSource().getValue();  // Get the value entered in the search field
      var oTable = this.getView().byId("table1");  // Get reference to the table control
      var oBinding = oTable.getBinding("items");  // Get the binding for table items
      var aFilters = [];  // Initialize an empty array for filters

      var selectedStatus = this.sKey;  // Use the selected status filter

      // Apply status filter if selected status is not "ALL"
      if (selectedStatus !== "ALL") {
        var statusFilter = new Filter("Status", FilterOperator.EQ, selectedStatus);  // Filter for status
        aFilters.push(statusFilter);
      }

      // Apply additional search filters if the search field is not empty
      if (srchVal && srchVal.trim() !== '') {
        // Create filters for Empid, Name, Salary, and Status using the search value
        var searchFilterEmpid = new Filter("Empid", FilterOperator.Contains, srchVal);
        var searchFilterName = new Filter("Name", FilterOperator.Contains, srchVal);
        var searchFilterSalary = new Filter("Salary", FilterOperator.Contains, srchVal);
        var searchFilterStatus = new Filter("Status", FilterOperator.Contains, srchVal);

        // Group the filters together with an OR condition (any field match)
        var searchFilterGroup = new Filter({
          filters: [searchFilterEmpid, searchFilterName, searchFilterSalary, searchFilterStatus],
          and: false  // Use "OR" logic for the filters
        });

        aFilters.push(searchFilterGroup);  // Add the grouped filter to the filters array
      }

      // Apply the combined filters to the table
      oBinding.filter(aFilters);
    }
  });
});

 

3. Conclusion

By combining an Icon Tab Bar and a Live Search Field, we can create a powerful dual-filtering mechanism in SAPUI5.
This approach allows users to:

✔ First filter data by category (status)
✔ Then refine the results instantly using fuzzy search
✔ Reduce scrolling and improve data visibility
✔ Make the UI faster, more dynamic, and user-friendly

SAP Fiori for SAP ERP

entry.title: Timestamp Conversion for Different User Time Zones in ABAP
entry.content:
Hello Everyone!

Recently, I worked on a timestamp conversion issue related to user-specific time zones in SAP. The data stored in the SAP level was correct, but when displayed through an ABAP report, the timestamp appeared incorrect for some users.

After analyzing the issue, I found that the root cause was the conversion routine defined in the domain. This routine automatically converts timestamps based on the user's logon time zone, which caused mismatches during display.

In this blog, I will show how to resolve this issue by converting all timestamps to UTC before displaying them, ensuring consistent results for every user—regardless of their time zone or domain settings.

Problem Summary

  • The timestamp stored in the database table (ZDEL_INFO) was correct.

  • But when displaying the data in a report, the timestamp appeared incorrect for some users.

  • This happened because the domain of the timestamp field had a conversion routine (e.g., TZNTSTMPS).

  • As a result, SAP automatically converted timestamps based on each user's time zone.

Example:

Domain with Conversion Routine:

Table:

Report:

Solution Approach

  1. Read timestamp values from the database.

  2. Convert local timestamp → UTC timestamp using:

cl_kf_helper=>timestamp_local_zone_2_utc

3.Populate the final internal table with the corrected timestamp.

4.Display the data using CL_SALV_TABLE.

By converting timestamps to UTC, the displayed values remain consistent for all users.

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report ZTIMESTAMPS_USERS
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Purpose:
*&   This report reads delivery data from table ZDEL_INFO,
*&   converts local timestamps into UTC based on the user’s time zone,
*&   and displays the results using CL_SALV_TABLE.
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
REPORT ztimestamps_users.

TABLES: zdel_info.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_del,
       deliveryno TYPE zdel_info-deliveryno,
       material   TYPE zdel_info-material,
       deldate    TYPE zdel_info-deldate,
END OF ty_del.

DATA: lt_final TYPE TABLE OF ty_del,
      ls_final TYPE ty_del.


*START-OF-SELECTION.

START-OF-SELECTION.

SELECT * FROM zdel_info
        INTO TABLE (lt_del).

LOOP AT lt_del INTO DATA(ls_del).

ls_final-deliveryno = ls_del-deliveryno.
ls_final-material   = ls_del-material.
IF ls_del-deldate IS  NOT INITIAL.

CALL METHOD cl_kf_helper=>timestamp_local_zone_2_utc
          EXPORTING
            i_timestamp_local = ls_del-deldate          " Timestamp in user's local time
            i_time_zone       = sy-zonlo                " Current user's time zone
          RECEIVING
            r_timestamp_utc   = DATA(lv_tmstamputc).    " Converted UTC timestamp

ls_final-deldate = lv_tmstamputc.
        CLEAR lv_tmstamputc.

ENDIF.
APPEND ls_final TO lt_final.
ENDLOOP.

DATA: o_alv TYPE REF TO cl_salv_table.

  cl_salv_table=>factory(
      IMPORTING
        r_salv_table = o_alv
      CHANGING
        t_table      = lt_final ).

* Display the ALV
o_alv->display( ).

Output:

Explanation of Key Logic

1. timestamp_local_zone_2_utc

This method converts a timestamp from the user’s local time zone (based on SY-ZONLO) to UTC.

2. Why Convert to UTC?

UTC is a universal reference.
Once converted to UTC, the timestamp remains consistent, regardless of:

  • User logon time zone

  • System time zone

  • Conversion routines in the domain

3. Output Using SALV

CL_SALV_TABLE is used for a simple and clean ALV output without advanced configuration.

Conclusion

Handling timestamps in SAP can be challenging, especially when conversion routines and user time zones come into play.
By converting timestamps to UTC before displaying them, we avoid incorrect values and ensure reliable reporting across all users.
It will have been Very Helpful for Real Time users in Project works
this has a process of just like small solution  thank you...


ABAP Development 
ABAP Connectivity 
ABAP Extensibility

entry.title: Hierarchical ALV Using Factory Method in SAP ABAP
entry.content:
In this blog post, we’ll explore how to implement a Hierarchical ALV using the Factory Method of the CL_SALV_HIERSEQ_TABLE class.

Introduction

In many SAP ERP scenarios, business users frequently work with data that follows a natural master–detail relationship, such as customers and their contacts, vendors and their company-code assignments, or materials and their storage locations. Presenting such related datasets in a clean and intuitive format is critical for efficient decision-making.

While traditional ALV is highly effective for displaying single-level tables, it becomes less practical when dealing with multi-level or dependent datasets. For these situations, SAP provides Hierarchical ALV through the class CL_SALV_HIERSEQ_TABLE, allowing developers to present complex data relationships in an expandable, easy-to-navigate layout within SAP GUI.

This blog demonstrates how to create a hierarchical ALV using a vendor master table and its corresponding item details. The objective is to show how straightforward it is to bind two related datasets, define the hierarchy mapping, and display the result using SAP’s SALV framework—all with clean, maintainable ABAP code.

Scenario Overview

We will work with two custom tables:

  • ZVA_VENDOR_TA – Stores vendor master information (header level).

  • ZVA_VENDOR_ITEM – Stores vendor-specific or company-code-specific details (item level).

The goal is to display these tables in a hierarchical ALV, where each vendor (header) can be expanded to reveal its associated item entries (detail).

CODE:

REPORT ZVA_FACTORY_HIERACY_ALV.

" Declaration of internal tables and work areas for hierarchical ALV binding
DATA: LT_HIERSEQ TYPE SALV_T_HIERSEQ_BINDING,
      LS_HIERSEQ TYPE SALV_S_HIERSEQ_BINDING.

" Select vendor master data from custom table ZVA_VENDOR_TA
SELECT VENDERNO, NAME, CITY, POSTALCODE, EMAIL, ACCOUNTGROUP, PROCESSORGROUP, POSTINGBLOCK
  FROM ZVA_VENDOR_TA INTO TABLE (LT_VENDOR).

" Check if data is available in the LT_VENDOR table
IF sy-subrc = 0.

  " If vendor data exists, select corresponding vendor item details from ZVA_VENDOR_ITEM
  SELECT VENDERNO, COMPANYCODE, PERSONNELNUMBER, AUTHORGROUP, NTGEW, GEWEI, EKORG, STATUS
    FROM ZVA_VENDOR_ITEM INTO  TABLE (LT_VENDOR_ITEM).

ENDIF.

" Define the hierarchy relationship between the master and detail tables
LS_HIERSEQ-MASTER = 'VENDERNO'.  " Master key field (header level)
LS_HIERSEQ-SLAVE  = 'VENDERNO'.  " Corresponding key field in detail (item level)
APPEND LS_HIERSEQ TO LT_HIERSEQ. " Add the mapping to the hierarchy sequence table

" Create and display the hierarchical ALV using CL_SALV_HIERSEQ_TABLE
CALL METHOD CL_SALV_HIERSEQ_TABLE=>FACTORY
  EXPORTING
    T_BINDING_LEVEL1_LEVEL2 = LT_HIERSEQ       " Define the binding between header and item tables
  IMPORTING
    R_HIERSEQ               = DATA(LO_SALV_HIERSEQ) " Get reference to the hierarchical ALV object
  CHANGING
    T_TABLE_LEVEL1          = LT_VENDOR         " Pass header (vendor) data
    T_TABLE_LEVEL2          = LT_VENDOR_ITEM.   " Pass item (vendor details) data

" Display the hierarchical ALV
LO_SALV_HIERSEQ->DISPLAY( ).

Output :

Conclusion

Hierarchical ALV is a powerful tool for presenting master–detail datasets in an organized and interactive format. The class CL_SALV_HIERSEQ_TABLE significantly simplifies the development process by handling the hierarchy logic internally, allowing developers to focus on data retrieval and business requirements rather than UI complexity.

By implementing this approach, organizations can deliver reports that are not only visually clear but also easier for end users to navigate—especially when dealing with multi-level relational data. This technique remains highly relevant for SAP GUI-based reporting and continues to be an important part of the ABAP developer’s toolkit.

If needed, this solution can be extended to support additional hierarchy levels, custom toolbar functions, or integration with business logic, making it flexible enough for advanced reporting scenarios.

ABAP Development

entry.title: Re: Question on MDK Extension Project & Version Control B...
entry.content: Typically you would put your ZSAPAssetManager also under version control.   If you have additional changes to make you would make them in the same ZSAPAssetManager project.  When deploying the .cim files in the base SAPAssetManager project control what is used.  If you have multiple CIM project the .cim files are processed in alphabetical order.  So if two extension projects indicate the same file is modified, the last .cim file processed wins.

entry.title: Re: Export and Import statements using memory id Help
entry.content:
Hi,
You state that in debug the code in EXIT_SAPL0VRF_001 is hit for both shipping points.
In that case the memmory value should be 'Y' in both cases.
I deduct from your explanation that also the code in MV50AFZ1 is hit and for one of the shipping points it is no longer 'Y'.

The reasons I can think of why it is not working are:

  1. The value only gets set for the one shipping point and not for the second one.
    But you stated that this was checked in debug and should be fine (just wanted to mention it again to double check)
  2. The value gets cleared in the flow in between the two points.
    - This could be either that the memory ID is already used for something else somewhere in between, this is hard to find because it could really be anywhere.
    - The flow is just slightly different due to customizing, causing the non-working shipping point to use two sessions whereby the memory parameter is not available in a new session.

So, what can you do:

  1. Try to use a different memory parameter name, making it so specifically named that it is guaranteed to not be used anywhere
  2. Use singleton class to buffer the value instead of working with export/import, this would also have the benefit that where used can be leveraged to find where it is set/read at any point in the future. But mostly it will give certainty that it is not used anywhere yet.
    You can also use a watchpoint (or regular breakpoint) on the attribute of the singleton class to know exactly when it gets changed in the flow.
  3. Do a trace of both cases and check what is different. 
    This might take a lot of time.

I hope it can at least be of some use or bring new ideas for troubleshooting.

entry.title: Primary and Secondary keys concept in Debugging
entry.content:
Introduction

In this blog we will be discussing on Primary and Secondary keys concept in Debugging,

Primary keys uniquely identify each record, making it easier to trace and isolate errors with precision. Secondary keys provide alternative access paths and relational context, helping uncover integrity issues, performance bottlenecks or constraint violations during analysis. Together, they form the backbone of accurate and efficient debugging .

1.How to check Primary and Secondary keys in Debugging.

Let us consider the Standard table type which is having 3 primary Non-unique keys and 1 Non-unique secondary key as shown below

TYPES: 
   tt_t100 TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF t100 
   WITH KEY sprsl arbgb msgnr                " Primary Key 
   WITH NON-UNIQUE SORTED KEY lang_text      " Secondary Key 
     COMPONENTS sprsl text. 
 
DATA: t_t100 TYPE tt_t100. 
 
 
select * FROM t100 INTO TABLE @t_t100 UP TO 50 ROWS.

In debugging, double click on the Internal table t_t100 to observe the Primary and Secondary keys in Key dropdown.


2.How many Primary and Secondary keys we have and how we are differentiating them in Debugging.

Click on key /indexes Icon which is on left side of Attributes to see the number of keys, uniqueness and type of Internal table.

We can observe Primary key values in blue and Secondary keys value in Black

 

 

Conclusion

In debugging prospective, primary keys help pinpoint the exact record causing the issue, ensuring precision. Secondary keys provide relational context and highlight integrity or indexing problems, helps in explaining why the error occurred. Together, they deliver both accuracy and insight.

entry.title: Re: Tolerance Limit for Purchase Order

entry.title: Master Data Consistency Analyzer - MDCA
entry.content:
Introduction

MDCA tool (Master Data consistency Analyzer) was previously called as MICE (Master Data Inconsistency Evaluator).
It can be used to identify the data inconsistencies across applications.CVI (Customer vendor integration), BP (Business partner), Address etc that are configured to the MDCA framework. All the inconsistencies in an application can be identified in one go, or inconsistencies can be identified for specific objects based on the selection criteria. MDCA tool can be considered as a one stop solution to identify all data inconsistencies for an application which will eventually save a lot of time and effort and ensure seamless process flow.

Target audience

Functional expert

Release Status

This transaction MICE is in restricted release mode for exclusive use by SAP Support.

Results may not be accurate and may not reflect current state of data.

Do not execute this transaction without written guidance from SAP.       

Prerequisites

Before Implementing the notes in the sequence listed below, please read the SAP Note 3353957.

Implement the SAP Notes listed below in strict sequence. In case any Note implementation status is incorrect or incomplete, stop and report back the issue to SAP Support. Do not proceed further with the implementation without resolving implementation issues from previous Notes.

MDCA Framework Notes :

1. Note 2956974 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - Framework Note 1

    This Note contains the package 'S_BUPA_TOOLS' in which the MDCA framework objects are developed.

    There will be activation issues for other objects in this Note, as the DDIC objects will be created from the next Notes below.

    Just make sure the package 'S_BUPA_TOOLS' is created sucessfully during the implementation of this Note.

2. Note 3532897 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - Framework Note 2

3. Note 3500434 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - Framework Note 3

    Once the above 3 notes are implemented, implement the first note again as mentiond below.

4. Note 2956974 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - Framework Note 1

5. Note 3232130 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - Framework Note 4

6. Note 3362331 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - Framework Note 5

7. Note 3384523 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - Framework Note 6

8. Note 3472055 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - Framework Note 7

Post implementing above Notes, go to SE80 transaction,check and activate if there is any inactive objects in package 'S_BUPA_TOOLS'.

Business Partner ( BUPA ) Application Notes for MDCA Framework:

9. Note 3396047 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - BP Application Note 1

10. Note 3396036 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - BP Application Note 2

11. Note 3485146 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - BP Application Note 3

12. Note 3514136 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - BP Application Note 4

CVI Application Notes for MICE Framework :

13.Note 3512942 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - CVI Application Note 1

14. Note 3025283 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - CVI Application Note 2

Currently, there is no change Logs functionality enabled.

This will be automatically updated via the relevant SPs across relevant Releases.

Usage

MDCA tool can be launched using the transaction code MICE.

Active applications configured in MDCA framework will appear in the list and needs to be selected, which will enable the user to enter selection screen parameters for execution.

- Background Execution
The button ‘Execute in Background’ will help to run the tool in background which is advised when running for large number of inconsistencies.  The 'Find' option will find all the inconsistencies. All the inconsistency details along with their statuses will be stored in the spool and will be available in ‘Run History’ section post completion of the background job for display.

- Foreground execution
The foreground execution of MDCA tool will display an ALV with all the inconsistencies based on the selection parameters.

‘Run history’ section in the selection screen will store the details for each execution (Background and foreground) and can be used for analysis at a later point of time if required. Upon selecting an entry from run history, the details will be displayed in the ALV.

Basic Tech info

Transaction code MICEMVS can be used to display the standard applications and other configurations delivered by SAP. Master data, table field, parameters and message nodes will be configured for each application which will help in execution of the MDCA tool. The application registered with active status will appear on the MDCA tool. 

Transaction MICEMV can be used to register custom applications. Master data, table field, parameters and message nodes must be configured as per the design. The custom class should refer to interface MICE_IF_WRAPPER for successful registration.
For more detais, please check 3353957 - MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) :- Functional Details

Successful configuration will generate the include programs MICE_GENERATE1 and MICE_GENERATE2 which will be used for dynamic generation of selection screen fields in MDCA tool.

Message node must be maintained with message class and message number details along with parameters to be displayed in the MDCA tool output. The criticality field is used to prioritize the inconsistencies while listing in the output.

MICE transaction is used to launch the MDCA tool. The selection screen will be displayed based on the configurations in MICEMV and MICEMVS.

The screen fields will be displayed based on the application selected. The tool can be executed, either by providing basic field values or by providing additional filters based on 'Specific' parameter option. Please refer attachments 'Initial screen' and 'Specific Parameters'.

After execution, all the inconsistencies will be displayed based on the selection criteria provided.Inconsistencies can be analysed further by checking the message text and additional parameters. Please refer attachment 'MICE -Output Screen'.

How to get SAP support for this tool

entry.title: SAP-RPT-1: Enterprise AI for Relational Data Now Generally Available!
entry.content:
Recap on SAP-RPT-1

As announced in TechEd this year, SAP-RPT-1 (in short for Relational Pre-trained Transformer) is our first-ever relational foundation model. Unlike traditional large language models that works primarily with unstructured text, SAP-RPT-1 is a table-native model that excels at understanding and predicting on your relational business data.

As highlighted in our technology blog post, SAP-RPT-1 enables in-context learning on your relational business data. This allows you to use the model out-of-the-box to gain business insights from your data, without the need for model training or fine-tuning.

We are excited to announce the general availability of SAP-RPT-1, our first step forward in making AI work seamlessly with the structured data that powers your business.

Model Variants

We have released two commercial variants of SAP-RPT-1 to meet different enterprise needs.

  • SAP-RPT-1-small: fast and lightweight version for medium complexity prediction, where low latency / high prediction throughput is in focus.
  • SAP-RPT-1-large: most powerful version for more complex prediction scenarios, when most accurate predictions and lowest error rates are the primary objective.

Both models support (multi-class, multi-target) classification and regression with up to 128 simultaneous prediction rows and up to 10 simultaneous prediction columns.

Further characteristics can be seen from the following table:

 SAP-RPT-1-smallSAP-RPT-1-large
Max Context Length2k (2048) rows64k (65536) rows
Max Columns100256
Number of Target Classes2561024

Please note that target class limits are recommendations only and, depending on the specific settings, scenarios with substantially more target classes may be addressable in some cases.

For a balanced trade-off between prediction quality, inference speed and cost, SAP recommends using SAP-RPT-1-small with 500 – 2000 context rows, and SAP-RPT-1-large with 4000 – 8000 context rows. While individual scenarios may perform best in different settings, experimentation done at SAP has shown that these sizes work well for many enterprise use cases. It is also observed that SAP-RPT-1 often outperforms alternative methods on real-world enterprise data that contains semantics. Still, SAP recommends every customer to perform own experiments in the given application scenario on productive data for best outcomes.

Both models, SAP-RPT-1-small and SAP-RPT-1-large, are now available on SAP generative AI hub. With an AI Core instance under the extended plan, you will be able to access these model versions. and further technical information for each model version.

In addition to these commercial variants, SAP has released SAP-RPT-1-oss on Hugging Face. This is a more lightweight, open-source variant of SAP-RPT-1, which we also described in this research paper. It is intended to be used by researchers and enthusiasts for non-commercial purposes only.

How to Get Started with SAP RPT 1

RPT Playground

If you are new to SAP-RPT-1, we have a playground environment that allows you to test SAP-RPT-1 for free. It is mainly designed for exploration and building initial business cases with SAP-RPT-1. Please note that, in contrast to the commercial variants, the free version only allows predictions for up to 25 rows, 4 columns and 50 target classes. Also, rate limitations apply.

Generative AI hub

As mentioned, the model variants for SAP-RPT-1 will be available on SAP generative AI hub. You will need to first deploy your desired model variant before you can start making inferences to the deployed model.

If you are already using SAP generative AI hub, you can refer to our help documentation and can get a headstart with SAP-RPT-1. Else, worry not as we will walk you through a complete step-by-step guide in our next blog post – from deployment to your first inference with SAP-RPT-1!

Conclusion

SAP-RPT-1 is now generally available and ready to power your enterprise applications. With SAP-RPT-1-small and SAP-RPT-1-large, you have the flexibility to select the right version for your needs. To learn more on the model versions, you can visit our help guide for detailed information on model specifications, API specifications and best practices.

Ready to transform how your organization leverages AI? The future starts now with SAP-RPT-1. 🎯

entry.title: SAP EWM Layout oriented storage control (LOSC) behind the scenes
entry.content:
In SAP EWM space, LOSC feature plays an important role in every project. This blog will help you to understand the background logic with scenario specific understanding.  It is bit technical so don't be overwhelmed , I've tried to explain in simple terms. Hope it helps. Enjoy the blog .🙂

Scenario 1: Product WT creation from  /SCWM/ADPROD or against WHR with full with drawl.  No pick point check in source storage type


Configuration:

Source Storage type:

LOSC:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Execution:

Product WT create

 

 

 

 

 

 

Note: This scenario behaves the same way if your rounding rule is '5' where we round to the multiple of available stock in this case at HU level & it matches the requested pick quantity.

 

 

 

 

 

Debug mode:

We can  see  the  main  program on the top  and  also in the call stack.

The FM is /SCWM/ROUTING_LAYOUT_CHECK   is mainly to check for LOSC.


 

 

 

 

 

Inside the FM we can see the highlighted code which checks
1. IV_FLGHUTO ( HU WT flag) 

2.  IV_HOMVE ( Important field for LOSC* we will see this further)

3. LS_VT331-PPNTA ( Pick point field in source storage type)

If any of the above fields are having value then it will eventually go to the main LOSC determination FM /SCWM/TROUTL/DET

which will check the entry from LOSC config settings shown above.

We see the IV_HOMVE is coming with value 'A' which then eventually checked and updated LV_HOMVE with 'C'

 

 

 

 

 

So, the question is how this IV_HOMVE is getting the values. 🤔

Let's go 1 step back in debugging to get the answer.

This is coming from the  below FM '/SCWM/TO_SRC_HU_HOMOGEN_SET'

called inside the FM /SCWM/REM_BIN_DET_INT 😇

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

If we see now inside the FM we can see that system checks what is the WT quantity (CS_LTAP-VSOLM) ,100 KG as shown below

and is it matching with the HU quantity (LV_QUANTITY) ,100  KG as shown below.

If yes, then it will eventually pass CS_LTAP-MOVEHU with value 'A' and then CS_LTAP-HOMVE is  marked  'X'

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

So far, we have these values,

but if you recall IV_HOMVE value inside the FM /SCWM/ROUTING_LAYOUT_CHECK  was 'A' not 'X'.  Therefore, we still need to see where this value is being updated. 
Here it is 

 

 

 

 

 

Note: You can notice here, CS_LTAP- MOVEHU value is passed into IV_HOMVE not CS_LTAP-HOMVE.

Now if we continue, we can see that it finds the LOSC settings ,

finally we will  have 2 WT's- 1 HU WT (open) and waiting product WT.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Scenario 2: Product WT creation from /SCWM/ADPROD or against WHR with partial quantity. 

No pick point check in source storage type

 

 

 

 

In this case the requested quantity 10 KG (CS_LTAP-VSOLM) is not matching with full HU quantity 100 KG (LV_QUANTITY)

therefore the value will not be set & code will return in the below FM /SCWM/TO_SRC_HU_HOMOGEN_SET

 

 

 

 

This will eventually not qualify for LOSC. Skipping the main LOSC FM.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Finally creating only 1 Product WT.

 

 


Scenario 3 : The storage type have pick point active and we have HOMVE ( whole HU) A for partial and C for complete HU pick scenario.

Configuration:

Source Storage type:

 

 

LOSC:

 

 

Execution:

a. Product WT creation for partial picking-

 

 

 

 

 

Debug Mode:

As pick point flag is active it will  always be going into the FM /SCWM/TROUTL_DET  via  /SCWM/ROUTING_LAYOUT_CHECK.

IV_HOMVE is initial, so it is passing 'A' into LV_HOMVE

 

 

 

 

It found the LOSC entry with IV_HOMVE ='A'

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Finally creating 2 WT's- 1 active HU WT and 1 waiting product  WT

 

 

Similarly, lets see the complete HU pick case.

b. Product WT creation for complete HU picking.

The LOSC will find the correct entry with HOMVE ='C' and create the tasks.

 

 

 

 

Debug mode:

We can see that system has found LOSC searching with HOMVE value 'C'


 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Again, created 2 WT-s , 1 active HU WT and waiting product WT.


 

This concludes the blog. Thanks for reading and do share your comments.


Disclaimer:  Above logic is tested in demo systems but actual project scenarios might be different so please do the required due-diligence.


Best Regards,

Y K B B Rudra Narayan

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Data Exchange goes WalkMe
entry.content:
Exchanging sustainability data across supply chains can feel complex, especially when requirements are new, data formats differ, and time is limited. SAP Sustainability Data Exchange is designed to make this process easier for both customers and suppliers by providing a secure platform for sharing standardized sustainability information.

To ensure everyone can get started quickly and confidently, SAP is investing in guided onboarding and in-application support, tailored specifically to external users.

Support from Day One: Onboarding Video Available Today

If you are a supplier or customer new to SAP Sustainability Data Exchange, help is already available.

SAP provides an onboarding video that walk you through the whole set-up of the free supplier license (SAP Store).

That video allows you to familiarize yourself with the solution before or during onboarding, so you know what to expect and can avoid unnecessary delays.

What’s Coming Next: In-Application Guidance with WalkMe (April 2026) 

Starting in April, SAP Sustainability Data Exchange will introduce WalkMe, an in-application guidance tool that supports you directly inside the platform.

Instead of searching for manuals or contacting support, WalkMe will:

  • Guide you step by step through tasks inside the solution
  • Provide contextual tips exactly where you need them
  • Help you complete data submissions more easily and accurately

This means you can focus on your data and business and not on learning a new system.

Why This Matters for Suppliers

For suppliers, sustainability data requests are increasing, often driven by customer requirements or regulations. WalkMe helps by:

  • Making onboarding faster and clearer
  • Reducing uncertainty around data entry
  • Minimizing errors and rework

You don’t need to be an SAP expert. The platform guides you through each step as you work.

Why This Matters for Customers

For customers requesting sustainability data from suppliers, guided onboarding means:

  • Faster supplier participation
  • Better data quality and consistency
  • Less manual follow-up and fewer clarification loops

When suppliers can onboard smoothly and submit data correctly the first time, everyone benefits.

A Simpler, More Supportive Experience

SAP Sustainability Data Exchange is designed to support collaboration, not create additional complexity. By combining onboarding videos available today with in-application guidance through WalkMe starting in April, SAP Sustainability Data Exchange helps customers and suppliers work together more efficiently from the very beginning.

Whether you are sharing data or requesting it, SAP Sustainability Data Exchange aims to make sustainability collaboration clear, guided, and scalable.

entry.title: Digitalization in Cell & Gene Therapy: Why Start Early and How to Scale
entry.content:
Introduction

As someone working at a small or emerging biopharma organization, I'm sure you've recognized this scenario before: there just aren't enough hours in the day and then there's always some new scientific milestone that demands focus. Even discussing new technologies, much less researching or implementing them, feels like a luxury. It makes sense that your focus centers on finding and developing life-changing and life-saving therapies. But it is also where digitalization becomes quietly and increasingly important.

At SAP, we believe that our role should be to amplify your scientific breakthroughs. By offering the correct digital platform, your organization can scale your innovation with confidence, knowing that all therapies are processed, controlled, and administered properly.

Why Digitalization Matters for Cell and Gene Therapy

Of all the therapeutic areas, advanced personalized therapies remains the most complicated; it requires perfect coordination among patients, manufacturers, couriers, clinics, and partners. Digital orchestration plays a critical role in:

  • Minimizing human-generated errors
  • Enhancing regulatory compliance
  • Support scaling as therapies transition from clinical trials through to commercial launch

Investing in digitalization is not solely an issue of operational efficiency. It enables biotechnology firms to focus on their core competency-developing therapies that change lives. Mixed with strong digital orchestration, breakthrough science will mean: The right therapy reaches the right patient, at the right time - safely, reliably, and at scale.

SAP Cell and Gene therapy Orchestration

SAP CGTO is designed to simplify and secure the complex orchestration of advanced personalized therapies. Here’s what makes it powerful:

  • Manage each step of supply chain orchestration
  • Integrate with partners (Sponsor/CMO) and logistics providers
  • Enable label management and integration
  • AI-enabled exceptions management
  • Integrate with SAP S/4HANA out of the box
  • Track and report Chain of Identity (COI) and Chain of Custody (COC) across systems
  • Built-in analytics

Support for Early-Stage Clinical Trials

Early-stage clinical trials come with unique constraints, and smaller biotech need to carefully weigh the costs of implementing digital solutions. SAP's approach ensures that companies can engage with us without financial considerations holding them back from innovation. 

Key strategies included offering a configurable, standalone, GxP-compliant solution for early-stage clinical trials that would minimize upfront investment and complexity while keeping audit readiness. As programs progress toward commercialization, the platform supports incremental integration with ERP systems, CMOs/CDMOs, and courier partners. This phasing reduces risk, preserves validated workflows, and ensures scalability.

Business & Technical Benefits

Investment in digitalization with SAP has several strategic advantages

  • Faster time-to-value with proven industry-standard solution
  • Risk reduction with compliance features (GxP, PHI protection, audit trails)
  • End-to-end orchestration for chain-of-identity and custody
  • Future-proof design aligned with SAP Life Sciences’ roadmap and consortium updates
  • Clean core architecture lowers TCO and eliminates extensive custom build and maintenance effort
  • Cloud-native scalability powered by SAP BTP

Let’s Discuss

How are you approaching digitalization in your CGT programs? What challenges have you faced in early-stage trials? Share your thoughts below!

Conclusion

SAP’s Cell and Gene Therapy Orchestration solution provides an integrated platform that supports orchestration, compliance, and scalability, enabling life-science organizations to effectively manage personalized therapy processes. As teams advance next-generation treatments, the question is no longer whether digitalization is needed, but how early the right digital foundation should be adopted to support scientific progress without disruption.

 
Finally, if cost is stopping you from going digital, lets chat !! 🤝

Thankyou & Regards!

Monika Birdi

entry.title: The Future of Ops: Scaling Fast, Higher Security With AI
entry.content:
In my two decades of helping organizations modernize their technology landscape, I’ve observed that one principle never changes — the faster we innovate, the more complex our operations get. The shift towards cloud adoption, continuous delivery, and agility has become unwavering, but it also reveals the fundamental gaps in traditional IT operations. 

For this reason, I firmly believe the future belongs to those who implement an AI-First Ops strategy - not just to automate workflows but also for integrating intelligence and adaptability into the core operations. So, just ‘doing things faster’ won't cut it anymore. We need to take more intelligent, data-driven decisions that equally consider speed, security, and scalability without compromising quality. 

From Automation to Intelligence 

For years, businesses were dependent on rule-based automation for reactive systems. It helped execute predefined tasks with "if-this-then-that" logic rules, but lacked some perspective. This worked well when the infrastructures were simpler, but with today’s cloud-native, hybrid, and distributed environments, it calls for extra action. Hence, nowadays more than 80% of executives leverage AI-based automation for their business processes. 

In an AI-First Ops model, we shift from rule-based systems to adaptive learning ecosystems. AI consistently examines event data, metrics, and logs across the organization to predict failure, identify anomalies, and even address the issues before they lead to consequences. 

Machine learning algorithms and models are now capable of connecting millions of events instantly within seconds, which usually takes hours or days. This is about more than just speed; it’s about converting data into valuable insights, which allows enterprises to drive innovation proactively and confidently. 

Integrating the Three Core Elements: Speed, Security, and Scalability 

Every CIO and CTO I have worked with encounters the same trio of obstacles – how to expand without falling out of control, and how to speed up the delivery without sacrificing security. The AI-First Ops model provides a structure to balance these conflicting demands. 

Speed: Latest Golden Standard in Innovation  

In today’s high-tech landscape, speed provides organizations with a competitive edge. Clients demand instant updates, intuitive experiences, and flawless uptime. Yet, traditional IT workflows struggle to thrive because they’re still response-driven. 

AI helps predict these issues before they even happen. Just imagine your AI-driven system recognizing performance degradation issues hours before a technical failure and rectifying issues without manual intervention or automatically reallocating resources. Well, that’s not a futuristic trend; it’s what modern AIOps platforms help with. 

In one project based on enterprise transformation, I observed that AI-powered predictive maintenance reduces resolution times by 50% and minimizes incident frequency by 40%. This helped teams with additional time and higher focus on innovation. 

That’s the core of AI-First Ops: restoring focus and efficiency.  

Security: Smarter Resilience in Action 

As organizations are leveraging remote and multi-cloud models, there’s an exponential rise in attack surface. Yet many businesses find security as an additional part rather than an integrated feature. This needs to change. 

AI helps integrate intelligence directly into resilience. By examining behavioral patterns, AI-powered systems can spot anomalies that alert to possible threats. 

At Radixweb, we’ve helped organizations deploy AI-driven adaptive cybersecurity frameworks. These cutting-edge systems produce prioritized alerts for analysts, automatically isolate suspicious workflows, and evaluate incidents based on contextual risks. 

This is where AI stands out — not just in solving issues proactively but also in building systems to predicting them. It transforms security into an adaptive process that reacts as quickly as attackers. And for tech leaders, it translates into the freedom to innovate fearlessly. 

Scalability: Expansion made Seamless 

Scaling a system is not a Herculean task. Scaling them smartly — that’s the real challenge. As operations scale, the visibility often diminishes. Teams might face complexity spirals, an unpredictable rise in workloads, and lose control of cloud expenses. 

AI-first Ops model restores clarity via data-based scalability. AI models help businesses grow, adjust workloads, forecast demands, and even enhance resource allocation based on utilization patterns. 

I worked with a global enterprise that used AI to predict seasonal traffic trends. So, instead of overallocating resources just to be safe, their systems now scale automatically in real time, saving nearly 35% in yearly cloud expenses while maintaining efficiency. 

This kind of intelligence not only minimizes cost, but also ensures resilient growth. 

Embedding an AI-Driven Ops Mindset 

Integrating AI technology alone won’t help organizations achieve ‘AI-first tag’. It’s a cognitive shift — one that combines people, process, and data. Over the years, I’ve seen the organizations who follow these key principles that successful adopters: 

  • Unify your Data First 
    Your AI systems are only as good as the data it learns from. Centralize your operational data including logs, traces, metrics into a single observability layer. Because scattered data results in scattered intelligence. 
  • Design Continuous Learning Loops 
    AI should evolve with time. You can integrate feedback loops from incident resolutions, system productivity, and user behavior to keep models adaptive, accurate, and on track.  
  • Integrate AI into DevOps Pipelines 
    Don’t just consider AIOps as a standalone function. Integrate it throughout the CI/CD processes for automated testing, validation, and rollback. Unifying DevOps and AIOps sustains a continuous learning and improvement ecosystem. 
  • Prioritize Explainability 
    As tech leaders, we have to believe AI decisions, however, this belief majorly comes from transparency. You can leverage explainable AI (XAI) to ensure your teams understand why some models make certain suggestions. 
  • Team Empowerment 
    Upskilling is the most crucial part of empowering your team. You can help and encourage your IT teams to go from administrators to strategists — experts who can easily interpret AI insights and drive automation with business goals. 

AI-First Ops Strategy: Unlocking Business Impact Beyond IT  

An AI-First Ops strategy is not just limited to IT — it’s a growth catalyst. The influence goes far beyond traditional performance indicators: 

  • Adherence to compliance protocols solidifies since AI is consistently enforcing audit readiness and governance. 
  • Innovation accelerates because teams can iterate faster and are free to experiment. 
  • There's a reduction in operational costs due to the automation of redundant tasks and resources optimization. 
  • Client experience improves as digital solutions get more responsive and downtime reduces. 

Paving the Way for Autonomous Enterprises 

I often say that AI-First Ops marks the beginning of a significant transformation towards autonomous businesses—a future where AI-based systems are self-learning, self-healing, self-improving, and self-guarding. 

However, this self-governance doesn’t refer to a lack of control. It relates to intelligent control, where human knowledge drives AI accuracy. The objective isn’t substituting your employees, it's empowering them.  

As business leaders, it's our role to balance these aspects — speed, security, and scalability — with an objective. AIOps allows us to align these elements, ensuring faster execution, secure processes, and higher scalability.  

The businesses that strike the perfect equilibrium will pioneer the next era of digital leadership. And I firmly believe that those embracing the AI-First Ops mindset will set the benchmark for the future.

entry.title: Re: Set time account booking end date after account valid...
entry.content:
Hi @MeiBoon50 

There are 2 ways to do this extension in time account. 

Configuration 1:-  Setting the "Account Booking Offset [Months]" to 12 in the time account always set the time account booking until be always 12 months extension compare to the account valid till.  

Configuration 2:- Creating the interim rule to extend the current calendar year to 12 months, which will extend only the Booking until date.

In both the conditions only booking end date will be extended and time account validity will be only for the current calendar year.

Above mentioned configurations are system driven approach and it allows employees to utilise the balance till the booking end date even though the time account validity is in past. 

Configuration 1 will set whenever time account is created, no need any additional set up or run. 

Configuration 2 has to be triggered from the time off calendar. 

Thanks & Regards

Arun

entry.title: Impact of de-globalization on instance strategy
entry.content:
Summary

With geopolitical tensions growing and governments becoming more protectionistic in policy-making, enterprises are preparing for a more localized, de-globalized world. This article describes observations from the SAP Transformation Hub on the impact on instance strategy and gives advice on what enterprises should consider when making decisions on their instance strategy.

 

Decision making on Instance Strategy

SAP has a proven methodology and best practice criteria that have helped hundreds of enterprise customers of all sizes to make decisions on their instance strategy. The set of criteria is explained in this blog and a whitepaper that describes considerations for splitting and consolidating instances is available for download here. Due to the increase of relevancy and growing interest in de-globalization, 2 new criteria have been added recently: geopolitical risks and legal compliance.

 

What aspects on de-globalization should enterprises consider? 

1. Enterprises with multinational operations are confronted with increasing geopolitical risks impacting their IT landscape. Proper risk management requires examining different scenarios from sanctions and export control for technology, data espionage, control cross border data flow to sudden disruption of data transfer. Changes in geopolitical situations may require re-assessing instance strategy options. The resilience of the architecture to sustain events needs to be looked at. Drawing on enterprise architecture dimensions enhances the assessment of instance strategy in the context of geopolitical risks

    1. Business Architecture: In times of crisis, countries may try to protect their economy by regulations and limitations such as mandatory business operations completely in the country and control data residency and flow. Consequently, enterprises need to be able to operate critical capabilities locally to ensure business continuity. Turning to business architecture helps evaluate which capabilities are critical for operations in countries at risk. If risk assessment concludes to proactive risk mitigation, these capabilities could be encapsulated and supported by local ringfenced building blocks, e.g. for order-to-cash on a local ERP while consolidating local finance in a corporate system.
    2. Application Architecture: for countries-at-risk, the criticality of operations running on global applications needs to be evaluated. A local instance may be required, or local data persistence in the form of archiving may need to be established. To achieve the desired level of resilience in critical areas, applications need to be duplicated and deployed locally to ensure continuity in times of crisis.
    3. Data Architecture: Questions that guide towards a proper assessment of the risk can include: Which types of data are being processed? How critical is the data? Where does the data flow and reside physically? What are the security and privacy measures implemented? Is there end-to-end encryption? Can I afford exposing my global data to governmental intelligence services? What would happen if the data would suddenly not be available? How difficult are changes to data provisioning?
    4. Technical Architecture: Relevant questions for assessing the risk include: Where are my data centres located? Are there sufficient security measures implemented in data centre operations? Where are my cloud vendors located? Under which jurisdiction do they operate?

It is impossible for global acting enterprises to be completely free from geopolitical dependencies. The more transparency into enterprise architecture is available in all dimensions, though, the easier it is to identify and mitigate risk.

 

2. An increasing number of new laws and regulations are being issued by governments all over the world around data protection and cybersecurity, which forces global acting enterprises to adapt.  Prime examples of recent years include the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) in the EU, the General Data Protection Law (LGPD) in Brazil or the China Personal Information Protection Law (PIPL) in China, which provides similar measures.

Usually, governments give enterprises time to become compliant with new laws. Enterprises first need to interpret and determine what it means for their operations before implementing concrete measures in their systems.

 

Trends in Customer's decision making

In the past, we have observed a trend across industries for consolidation of instances. Driven by the availability of scaling infrastructure, large enterprises with global operations were able to realize considerable business benefits by harmonizing business processes and simplifying landscapes. Those enterprises whose business is truly global in nature were able to benefit from capabilities such as single source of truth for customer, inventory, etc. as well as more LoB specific functions such as global supply chain planning. The trend towards consolidation in general continues but we have observed situations where customers have deviated from plans of a single global instance and shifted to a more modular architecture driven by considerations on de-globalization. A controlled decoupling of critical applications is an approach enterprises are following to better manage risks. The higher the geopolitical risk, the more attractive are sovereign cloud options which are now evolving fast in response to customer demand.

 

Conclusion

Decisions on instance strategy have a large impact on transformation programs and require a holistic perspective with considerations on business strategy, IT operations, deployment and technology. While aspects on deglobalization gain in importance, enterprises need to integrate geopolitical risk and legal compliance when making instance strategy decisions.

While implementing laws and regulation can be planned, geopolitical risk requires a different treatment. Landscape options should be evaluated considering resilience towards mitigating geopolitical risks and how regulation on data privacy, protection and localization can be facilitated. Landscape options providing higher agility and resilience towards possible geopolitical disruptions and those that are easier to adapt to new regulation are becoming more attractive.

entry.title: 🇮🇳 SAP Build: Advanced Event Mesh - Event based SAP Build Process Automation (Bengaluru, India)
entry.content:
This is the all-new SAP CodeJam for SAP Build low-code/no-code tooling that focuses on giving you hands-on experience for building event-triggered processes with SAP Build Process Automation.

You will build an event-based scenario that lets users create S/4HANA business partners, setting off a process where:
  1. An employee approves the creation of a site access badge.
  2. A second employee, determined based on the details of the business partner, may also need to approve the badge.
  3. The process calls an external, 3rd-party badge system and waits to be called back.
  4. A user creates the badge and the badge system calls back the process instance.
  5. A notification with the badge ID is sent.

 

The scenario is built in 2 halves:
 
SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh: You will learn about events, CloudEvents, events in the SAP landscape, the process for publishing and subscribing to events, and your way around SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh. Then, you will create a REST Delivery Point in advanced event mesh to forward events to your SAP Build on your SAP BTP trial account.
 
SAP Build Process Automation: You will create a process from scratch to handle the issuance of site access badges. You will learn the basics of SAP Build Process Automation (projects, triggers, conditions, creating instances, monitoring, and the Inbox), and also use some of the more recent or advanced features (event triggers, form events, waiting for a API callback).
 
Prerequisites
  • Bring your own laptop with power adapter and have a supported Web browser such as Google Chrome or Firefox installed on your laptop.
  • It can be helpful to bring a tablet or second laptop, if you have.
  • Complete these prerequisites and the required reading BEFORE you come: 
    • Introduction to the CodeJam
    • Prerequisites
    • Required reading:
      • 1 - Exploring Events and More in the SAP Business Accelerator Hub
      • 2 - Why Event-Driven Architectures?

Location and Date

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Thursday, January 29th, 2026 from 9:30 - 16:00 local time in Bengaluru, India. The language of the event and the content will be English. 

Event Address:  Ericsson Global, AQUAMARINE WTC 03 and CITRINE WTC 04, Bagmane World Technology Centre, SEZ, Outer Ring Road, Bengaluru, Bengaluru Urban, Karnataka, 560048

Google maps location: https://maps.app.goo.gl/xJHoXAdLbEHKR9CHA 

  • The instructors are SAP Developer Advocates  @ajay_soreng  and @Rekha_DR 
  • Thank you Ericsson Global for hosting this event.

Please note that spaces are limited! We can only accommodate 30 attendees. If you want to attend, register by clicking the Yes button in the Will you be attending? section above to the right. About two weeks before the event, you will be asked to confirm your attendance via email.

entry.title: Re: SAP Intercompany Processes: STO with Billing step by step guideline
entry.content:
Hi Harsh_Joshi,

In an intercompany STO scenario, the billing document is indeed created first by the supplying company after goods issue. This intercompany billing document is then sent to the receiving company, and invoice verification (MIRO) is carried out with reference to this billing document, not directly against the delivery.

So the sequence is:
Goods Issue --> Intercompany Billing --> Invoice Verification in receiving company.

Hope this clarifies your doubt.

Regards,

Leelamohan

entry.title: Re: Making SAP Business One Web Client accessible externally using nginx as a reverse proxy
entry.content:
Hi @Andre_S 
Thanks for your comment.
You are right, within current B1 Architecture, components have dependency on SLD and Authentication service at runtime for landscape discovery, user authentication and tenant/DB resolution.
As a result both SLD and Authentication service need to be accessible. By using  the Nginx template you can minimize exposure to a single URL and Port for both.
Any deviation from this setup would require a deep ARC change I'm affraid.
Feel free to share your idea for potential future improvements and get community's vote on it via Customer influence https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/campaign/887 

Best Regards
Guy

entry.title: Cleaning Zero and Blank Base Cost Records in SAP Analytics Cloud BW Live for Clear Variance Trends
entry.content:
Business Background

In BW Live–based cost analysis, variance trends are often affected by records that contain zero or blank Base Cost values.
These records usually belong to:

  • Old projects
  • Pass-through orders
  • Closure or migrated projects

Including them in trend analysis makes charts noisy and less meaningful for management discussions.

 

What the Execute Button Does

When the user clicks the Execute button:

  • WBS TOPs with zero or blank Base Cost values are removed
  • The remaining records are used to calculate:
    • Approximate cumulative variance
    • Year-wise variance trend
  • The chart becomes easier to read and interpret

At the same time, the story still provides:

  • One table and chart with all records
  • One table and chart without zero or blank records

This gives full transparency to the user.

 

Important Business Clarification

Removing these WBS TOPs does not impact the actual variance calculation in a material way.

Reason:

  • Zero or blank Base Cost values appear mainly in Main projects
  • These projects are mostly old or pass-through in nature
  • Proper Base Cost and Actuals are correctly tracked in Sub- projects

So the filtered view improves visual clarity, not financial accuracy.

 

Design Approach in SAP Analytics Cloud

The solution uses a helper table–based dynamic filtering pattern.

High-level logic:

  1. Read data from a helper table
  2. Identify WBS TOPs with non-zero Base Cost
  3. Collect only valid WBS TOP IDs
  4. Apply the filter dynamically to:
    • Main chart
    • Main table
  5. Remove the filter automatically if no valid records exist

This logic runs only when the user clicks Execute, keeping the story fast.

 

Simplified SAC Script

// Source helper table

var dsSource = Table_Helper.getDataSource();

 

// Target chart and table

var dsTargetChart = Chart_Main.getDataSource();

var dsTargetTable = Table_Main.getDataSource();

 

// Read result set

var rs = dsSource.getResultSet();

var validWbsList = ArrayUtils.create(Type.string);

 

// Collect WBS TOPs with non-zero and non-blank Base Cost

for (var i = 0; i < rs.length; i++) {

    var wbs = rs[i]["DIM_WBS_TOP"];

    var measure = rs[i]["@MeasureDimension"];

 

    if (measure && measure.formattedValue !== "0" && measure.formattedValue !== "") {

        validWbsList.push(wbs.id);

    }

}

 

// Apply or remove filters

if (validWbsList.length > 0) {

    dsTargetChart.setDimensionFilter("DIM_WBS_TOP", validWbsList);

    dsTargetTable.setDimensionFilter("DIM_WBS_TOP", validWbsList);

} else {

    dsTargetChart.removeDimensionFilter("DIM_WBS_TOP");

    dsTargetTable.removeDimensionFilter("DIM_WBS_TOP");

}

 

Why This Pattern Works Well

Technical Benefits

  • Fully compatible with BW Live
  • No hard-coded filters
  • Clean and reusable scripting
  • No impact on backend data

Business Benefits

  • Clear variance trends
  • Better year-wise comparison
  • Transparent view for auditors and controllers
  • Faster management discussions

 

Conclusion

Using an Execute button to remove WBS TOPs with zero or blank Base Cost values is a simple yet powerful way to improve variance trend analysis in SAP Analytics Cloud. By combining helper tables and dynamic dimension filtering, you get better insights without compromising data integrity.

entry.content:
Hello @pkovac, 

SAP-RPT-1 is now generally available on SAP generative AI hub in 2 model versions - SAP-RPT-1-small and SAP-RPT-1-large - under both sap-internal or extended plans. Similar to the LLMs, the model versions will be available in the Model Library within generative AI hub. You can use SAP AI Launchpad to navigate AI Core functionalities.

Do read our latest blog post, where we explained the model versions in detail. We will also be releasing a second blog post shortly which contains a step-by-step guide on how to get started with SAP-RPT-1.
